text: Bottle: &nbsp Soft cocoa, maple syrup, and some chiles on the tongue. &nbsp It has a chile aspect but not the heat. &nbsp Fairly sweet. &nbsp Pretty tasty overall. &nbsp Its weird, I keep expecting heat because of the chile flavor, but it doesnt show up. &nbsp Moderate body and mouthfeel. &nbsp Interesting sweet beer. &nbsp Cocoa powder, maple syrup and chile flavor is what I seem to get most, but no heat. &nbsp Very interesting beer to say the least. &nbsp Thanks Bill!
Really good, like a stack of pancakes. Kinda butter. Thanks tony b. Tasted at Tims bottle share.

HMOG 2015. At the tail end of a crazy day, this one managed to awanken the palate. Timing and placing perfection for me. Vanille, coffee, cocoa on top of a lively golden brew. Heavy sweet competed nicely with the 30 other brews I had.
Bottle. Weekly tasting. Pours gold white head. Nose/taste of coffee, vanilla, pancake malt and vanilla. Some chocolate. Medium body.
Bottle. Orange pour tan head. Mild sweet tones, light malty aromas. Flavors are sweet and malty, nothing over the top.

Pours orangish copper with a small white ring. Smells strongly like coffee. Taste is Golden Grahams cereal and coffee. Full-bodied with a smooth texture and soft mouth-carbonation, Armadillo Ale Works Brunch Money finishes with a lingering coffee bitterness.

Extra from a recent trade. Was expecting something a little more on the side of the stout equation but this pouts a bit more orange gold color. Very sweet. Lots of vanilla and chocolate. Some roasty malt. Syrupy and molasses. Ok bit a little too much on the sweet stuff.

Only complaint is that its a bit too boozy/too much alcohol heat. Otherwise, this is wonderful. Love the flavors. Seems like it should be a porter/stout, but its not -- rather, very good flavors, including  chocolate, maple, vanilla, and some other things going on. Quite good!

UPDATED: AUG 11, 2014 Bottle: Thanks, Jason. Light copper body, slightly murky with a white-ish head that fades to a collar quickly. Aroma of caramel, light maple syrup, honey, faint metallic toffee, just a hint of cocoa dust, some toasted crackers, & faint yeast. Taste has more vanilla & tastes like some sort of wafer cookie. Lightly sweep marscarpone & whipped cream sweetness with hints of maple, brown sugar, toffee, Werthers candy, butterscotch, vanilla bean, & very faint coffee grounds. Lots of stuff going on, a dry bread & yeast finish. A very unique beer here. Lots to wrap your head around, but pretty tasty when all is said & done.

Courtesy of Jason R
Bottle: The aroma consists of chocolate, light maple syrup, vanilla, and a hint of nuts. It pours a transparent copper with a small white head that quickly fades to a thin film outlined by a slightly thicker ring. The flavor starts with chocolate and caramel. He finish has light-moderate vanilla with a touch of nuts. Its medium bodied with light-moderate carbonation.

22 ounce bottle thanks to errl. A brunch golden ale? Interesting...poured into a brandy snifter. Pours a clear copper to burnt orange with a velvety head of beige foam. Pretty good retention. The aroma is definitely roasty and I get biscuit and syrup and honey. The taste delivers on the coffee while still delivering on the syrup aspects and bready notes that could be taken for pancakes. Thicker mouthfeel, a lot like I would expect in a stout. Moderate carbonation.

Pours hazy amber with frothy white head out of bottle. Aroma of caramel, spice, and malt. Taste of roasted cocoa, caramel, syrup, and malt. Good beer overall. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

On tap - deep rust color with a small head. Has a nice roast coffee aroma and a coffee and caramel taste. Seems like a stout but it isnt. Very nice. Not a huge herb/vegetable beer fan but I like this one.

Bottle thanks to rightcross55. Pours a hazy copper color with a small foamy head that fades to a nice ring. Very unique aroma. Jalapeno poppers, maple syrup, chocolate, vanilla pudding, coffee, and grease. Tastes like maple syrup and vanilla mostly. Also, getting caramel, coffee, and brown sugar. Very syrupy sweet. Medium to full body. Syrupy and sticky. Very unique beer all around. Either a breakfast or dessert beer I guess and I wish I wouldve opened this at a share. The strong sweetness and intense flavors will make it hard for me to finish the whole bomber. Very cool beer.
5/18/2014. 22 oz. bottle. Amber color with a white head. Coffee and chocolate aromas. Spicy flavors with light hops. A bit sticky, but an interesting beer.
Pours hazy golden with a creamy head. Tastes of cocoa with hints of vanilla and alcohol. Clean finish.
I guess this is what they call a white stout. Color is murky tan. Lots of vanilla. Maple syrup. Touch of coffee and chocolate. Decent stuff.

Dark amber pour with an off white head. Aroma is strong coffee, condensed milk, and maple syrup. Taste is coffee, sweet vanilla, syrup, and milk chocolate. A lot of layers. Sweet overall but not too heavy. I really enjoy this beer.
On tap at Big Texas Beer Fest. Orange pour with a small head. Aroma is coffee and syrup. Taste is sticky, sweet with a side of coffee. Greasy spoon breakfast.

On tap at Big Texas Beer Fest and later at Jacks and Craft and Growler because I love this beer. Orange-copper pour with a white head. The aroma has a lot of cocoa and coconut notes, as well as a bit of maple. The flavor is very similar. The chocolate and maple notes mix very well with some brown sugar to make the beer taste a lot like chocolate covered waffles. Medium mouthfeel and medium carbonation. Great.

On tap at BTBF.
Golden amber brew w/ a bit of white head. Aromas of coffee, maple, honey sweetness - smells like Sunday morning! Flavors of chocolate, vanilla, maple, sweet finish. Very unique.

Pour is a dark clear gold with a small white head.,Nose is cereal, pancakes, maple syrup, dusty, caramels...Taste is nice vanilla and maple pancakes, whip cream, some dusty chocolate and nice sweetness..Alcohol is very well hidden.
Draft - Dark roast coffee. Clear copper with no head. Sweet almost syrup and coffee. Like an incredibly milky sweet coffee. Neat but a bit heavy.
Kind of like washing down chocolate frosted mini-wheats with a mug of coffee. So yeah, brunch totally works.
On tap at BTBF 2014. Amber in color with a decent off-white head. Aroma is of oats, light chocolate, caramel, and toffee. Taste is of caramel, oat cookie, light chocolate and roasted malts.

Tap at the BTBF. The look is clear, golden to orange in color, and has an off white head. The smell has a whift of smoke, cocoa, sweet, different and ok. The taste is grain, wheat, bread, cocoa, coffee cake thing.
BTBF. Cloudy orange color. OMG huge coffee aroma, chocolate, honey and grains. Big hersheys chocolate flavor, more bitter chocolate, sweetness. This is badass.

On draught at Libertine in Dallas. Pours a clear dark amber color with a medium foamy off-white head that diminishes gradually. Patches of lacing on the glass. Aroma of roast malt, chocolate and coffee. Full-bodied with flavors of roasted coffee, chocolate malt and a touch of fruit. The finish is roasty with a mocha aftertaste. Interesting beer overall, above average.

At the Big Texas Beer Fest on 4/5/2014. Draft pours bronze. Aroma is cocoa nibs, chocolate, no presence of roasted malt so the chocolate notes and kinda like hot chocolate, molasses, caramel. Taste is huge cocoa powder, little bit of sweet maltiness in a good way. IT is actually pretty nice and interested and hides the alcohol really well.
Gold/copper with a cream head. Nose is coffee, syrup, chocolate and sweet. Great palate, coffee up front, syrup, toffee in the back, sticky, smooth finish.
